intro: Mascagnia septentrionalis, commonly known as the Florida moccasin vine, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Apocynaceae family, which includes many toxic plants. The plant produces showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that are typically pink or red in color. It has a climbing habit and features opposite, ovate leaves with a slightly hairy surface. The plant is adapted to grow in sandy, well-drained soils and is often found in coastal areas.
